body: @mistercrunch @pkexcellent https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/680 You may want to reopen this bug.

I'm keeping this issue open as it may impact other people. I worked around it by: 
1. Changing my dag_id to `my_dag_v2` from `my_dag_v1`
2. Restarting the webserver and scheduler

The result was that it started a new DAG with no-history. The old DAG disappeared from the UI. The system honored the start-time of my new hourly DAG.

Indeed, looks like there was a problem in `run_unit_tests.sh` that was preventing the extra nose arguments in Travis. It should be fixed now.

On the other hand I'm not sure if the coverage captures what's being launched through the `subprocess.Popen` in the `SequentialExecutor` that's used by `tests/dagtest/dag_tester.py`. Any idea how this would apply ? https://coverage.readthedocs.org/en/latest/subprocess.html
Thanks, that resolved my issue.
@mistercrunch travis is complaining about something unrelated.
Can someone help me how to test an external service? I am developing an AWS ECS operator.
Can you test that it is still the case on `1.6.2`? I reviewed the related 1.6.2 code and I can't think of any reason why these task instances wouldn't get skipped.
I don't understand how these empty files in the project work along with systemd.

That's a very good question. They should not be empty of course. Weird, I'll fix that.

I didn't see a tag for 1.6.2, but I pulled head from master. I confirmed the same broken behavior. There is additionally another problem as well, which I am tracking in a separate bug : https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/685
Are you using `airflow backfill` or some other entry point than the scheduler?
@MaximilianR The docs need to be updated ... ill submit a PR. A dag will fail if Slack is down ... (Slack went down for us today .. I am guessing you experienced the same)

I'm just running with a scheduler, webserver, and local executors. This is being observed in the UI and this is only triggered by schedulers running hourly. Last night, 6/12 runs failed due to a transient issue.. and the run failures were random. So, the 1am and 2am runs failed, then the 3am run succeeded, and the 4am run failed, etc... This morning I awoke to seem some failed and some succeeded. I quickly fixed the source of the transient failure and reran. I don't have a tree UI screen capture to share unfortunately. I can share the task details for one such task :
Is depends_on_past enabled here? If so I think it may be a byproduct of #680
Yes, "depends_on_past" is enabled. However, how are they related? It's easy for me to test this theory. I will go ahead and set it to "depends_on_past"=false and test it out.

depends_on_past currently means "the previous task instance for this DAG succeeded"

if that is the definition, it's somewhat incompatible with branching.

If the definition has to be changed, it's unclear what it should be changed to. Seem that whatever change would not be immediately intuitive whatever it may be.

Somewhat unrelated but I had issue with their python client and submitted a PR to their repo that they merged but haven't release on Pypi yet...
PR here:
https://github.com/slackhq/python-slackclient/pull/48

I thought everyone would have had the same issue we had, didn't you?
@mistercrunch we have not encountered this issue. I will try to replicate though.
Which version of Airflow and the Slack client are you running?
After disabling depends_on_past (i.e. setting it to False), this worked for me. Some documentation has been added at https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/a3dacf6684f8bab053fa6f1fbcf16aedf26d4e6a
The issue is that "depends_on_past:True" does not currently work well with branch operators.
For this to work, I need to change `depends_on_past` to false. I also needed to change my DAG so that the join point was not a direct child of the branch point. Here's my new DAG :

BTW, I noticed this happening on a plain-old BashOperator. In the DAG below, the `generate_new_parquet_spark_job` was failing and the next run would ignore that the previous hour's `generate_new_parquet_spark_job` had failed and go ahead and schedule the current hour's `generate_new_parquet_spark_job` to run. Unlike other issues that I filed today, this does not involve any branching.
Gone through all versions of Airflow and currently using slackclient (0.16)
Is it possible that you've been going back and forth with `depends_on_past` True/False and maybe it got triggered at some point where `depends_on_past == False`?
is START_DATE dynamic? because depends_on_past is disregarded for the start_date of a task (so that it can get started...).

Interesting, I'm not sure why we hit an error and you don't... You may want to try their trunk (branch master) and make sure it doesn't break your stuff. I'm pushing on them to release another version.
Getting the same thing with a fresh install 1.6.1.
Here was the fix https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/c4d0fe93ed8185114364984e5eafa1b1fc404a0c, it will make 1.6.2

Hi @timeisapear and @mistercrunch,

I believe @thoralf-gutierrez and myself have found an easy way to reproduce this issue as part as the unit tests. 

We created a small "end-to-end dag tester" that rely on a `BackFillJob` to execute a DAG and then validates some post-conditions. We believe this is already super useful now and can grow into a great tool that continuously validates the robustness of Airflow! The corresponding PR together with some examples of sucessfull tests is here: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/670.

We used this framework to test the trigger rules ALL_FAILED, ALL_DONE and ONE_FAILED (when executed in a `BackFillJob`) and noted that none of them trigger the execution of the corresponding task since the `BackFillJob` systematically removes it from the `tasks_to_run` list, in the code identified by @timeisapear [above](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/480#issuecomment-145597830). 

We're not submitting these 3 tests in a PR yet since they would break the build, though the code and the corresponding Travis build failure on our fork are visible below: 

https://github.com/RealImpactAnalytics/airflow/tree/testing_trigger_rules_v3
https://travis-ci.org/RealImpactAnalytics/airflow/jobs/94600932

We suggest the following resolution path: 

1) please review https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/670 and let us know if there's anything more we should do in order to have this validation framework included the master branch 

2) we could then submit another PR with the 3 supplementary tests above + a fix that, as suggested by @timeisapear, would simply allow downstream tasks to stay in the `tasks_to_run` list if they can be triggered by failures. 

What do you think ?

So I thought I'd leave some feedback.

@mistercrunch I can't replicate the issue. When I run the doc generation I only get warning about things in contrib. So I am unsure how to resolve it.

nevertheless I saw some things in the sphinx config that I think might need to be changed:

`sys.path.insert(0, settings.AIRFLOW_HOME + "/src/airflow")` is not existent in my environment. Something like `sys.path.insert(0, os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__name__), '../airflow'))` might work better?

Also copyright, and version info I think should be updated as well I think (googling for documentation always point to version 1.0.0 now which did confuse me in the past). I can have a go at it, but as your environment is spitting out errors different than mine I am a bit hesitant. But just say the word...

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/postgres_hook.py#L12

As a side note, autocommit in DbApiHook should probably be set in a different way, perhaps a `set_autocommit(cur, conn, autocommit=True)` method that receives an active cursor and connection object and does what it needs to do. Class deriving DbApiHook for specific DBs would have to implement it.
Yes, I just turned retries back on and it is working in 1.6.*

What do the scheduler logs look like? The scheduler logs are very verbose, and you should clearly see where it's stuck. 

We restart it every 5 runs using `--num_runs` mostly just to make sure we get a 100% refreshed dagbag. Keep in mind that this strategy doesn't work with LocalExecutor.

Latest PR uses pandas.io.gbq to create DataFrames. This allows Airflow/GBQ integration to support pagination, types in schemas, and long-running queries, among other things.

I have a tweaked implementation that just uses BaseHook. It's unclear to me the relation between BaseHook and DbApiHook. I can make both work with the BQ hook, but it seems like BaseHook is actually the correct one. Is this understanding right?
@bolkedebruin may actually have been a mistake on my end ... need to do a few more tests and will confirm ... thanks for the help though.

It makes no sense to use a batch workflow engine to run every second. Airflow is not meant for realtime and arguably not even for close-to-realtime. 

I'd suggest never going under 5 minutes. Hourly / daily is the zone of comfort. 5 minutes is probably overhead heavy.
@artwr fyi
@mistercrunch anything left to do?

OK - figured it out.  This one has to win the award for one of the most misleading error messages of all time.

The problem was this setting:

```
# Was
celery_result_backend = psycopg2://username:password@postgres:5432/default
# Should be
celery_result_backend = db+postgresql+psycopg2://username:password@postgres:5432/default
```

I originally had the same string I was using for my `sql_alchemy_conn` setting:

```
celery_result_backend = postgresql+psycopg2://username:password@postgres:5432/default
```

But that one failed in a different (more obvious) way.

Boo non-standard connection urls.

For those who come in the future, here are the relevent docs:
http://celery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/configuration.html#database-url-examples

Here's a feature request to celery to make the error messages more helpful:
https://github.com/celery/celery/issues/2945

NT4 support is on the roadmap, we'll then attack Windows Server 2000 and work our way up.

Hey can we move this in `airflow.contrib.hooks` to make it clear that it isn't unit tested and testable by the maintainers?

DbApiHook provides tons of methods provided that the database API follows the python spec defined here:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/

All of the db drivers implementing that standard can share a lot of code.
